sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Evaluate patients for TB (tuberculin skin test) prior to therapy; do not administer if active infection. Treatment of active or latent TB infection should be started prior to secukinumab therapy.
  • Plaque psoriasis (Moderate to Severe), In patients who are candidates for systemic therapy or phototherapy: Initial, 300 mg (2 injections of 150 mg) SUBQ at weeks 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4; some patients may only need 150 mg
  • Plaque psoriasis (Moderate to Severe), In patients who are candidates for systemic therapy or phototherapy: Maintenance, 300 mg (2 injections of 150 mg) SUBQ every 4 weeks; some patients may only need 150 mg

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Plaque psoriasis (Moderate to Severe), In patients who are candidates for systemic therapy or phototherapy

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Hypersensitivity to secukinumab or any component of this product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Gastrointestinal:
  • -- Exacerbation of Crohn's disease, sometimes serious, has been reported; exercise caution in and closely monitor patients with active Crohn's disease
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Infections have been reported, with an increased risk with increasing dose; monitoring recommended and discontinuation may be required if serious infection develops
  • -- Use caution in patients with chronic infection or a history of recurrent infection
  • -- Tuberculosis; do not administer to patients with active infection, treat latent TB prior to initiating secukinumab, and monitor for infection during treatment
  • -- Anaphylaxis and urticaria have been reported; discontinue if anaphylaxis or serious allergic reaction occur
  • -- Latex allergy; cap contains natural rubber latex
  • -- Completion of all age-appropriate vaccinations prior to treatment initiation is recommended
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- Avoid live vaccine administration during treatment

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

1.title: Major
1.mono:
• Adenovirus Vaccine Type 4, Live (theoretical)
  • Adenovirus Vaccine Type 7, Live (theoretical)
  • Alfentanil (theoretical)
  • Aminophylline (theoretical)
  • Artemether (theoretical)
  • Astemizole (theoretical)
  • Bacillus of Calmette and Guerin Vaccine, Live (theoretical)
  • Carbamazepine (theoretical)
  • Cisapride (theoretical)
  • Cyclosporine (theoretical)
  • Dihydroergotamine (theoretical)
  • Ergotamine (theoretical)
  • Fentanyl (theoretical)
  • Iloperidone (theoretical)
  • Influenza Virus Vaccine, Live (theoretical)
  • Lumefantrine (theoretical)
  • Measles Virus Vaccine, Live (theoretical)
  • Mumps Virus Vaccine, Live (theoretical)
  • Paclitaxel (theoretical)
  • Phenytoin (theoretical)
  • Pimozide (theoretical)
  • Poliovirus Vaccine, Live (theoretical)
  • Quinidine (theoretical)
  • Rotavirus Vaccine, Live (theoretical)
  • Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live (theoretical)
  • Sirolimus (theoretical)
  • Smallpox Vaccine (theoretical)
  • Tacrolimus (theoretical)
  • Terfenadine (theoretical)
  • Theophylline (theoretical)

  • Varicella Virus Vaccine (theoretical)
  • Warfarin (theoretical)
  • Yellow Fever Vaccine (theoretical)

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (2.6% to 4.1%)
  • Respiratory:Nasopharyngitis (11.4% to 12.3%), Upper respiratory infection (2.5% to 3.2%)
Serious
  • Gastrointestinal:Crohn's disease, Exacerbation (0.09%)
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Infectious disease (Up to 12 weeks, 28.7%; up to 52 weeks, 47.5%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Secukinumab is a human IgG1 monoclonal antibody that inhibits the release of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines by selectively binding to the interleukin-17A (IL-17A) cytokine and inhibits its interaction with the IL-17 receptor, a naturally occurring cytokine involved in normal inflammatory and immune responses.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Subcutaneous
  • Lyophilized powder, reconstitution: Healthcare professional use only; takes about 20 minutes to reconstitute but should not take more than 90 minutes; prepare the required number of vials (1 vial for the 150 mg dose or 2 vials for the 300 mg dose); inject 1 mL of room temperature sterile water; tilt vial 45 degrees and gently rotate for 1 minute; do not shake or invert vial; allow 10 minutes for dissolution; gently rotate vial for another minute; allow to stand undisturbed for 5 minutes; final concentration is 150 mg/mL
  • Lyophilized powder: Following reconstitution, use immediately or within 24 hours if stored in refrigerator
  • Sensoready(R) pen or prefilled syringe: the removable cap contains natural rubber latex and should not be handled by latex-sensitive individuals
  • Allow to reach room temperature (15 to 30 minutes) before injecting; administer within 1 hour after removing from refrigerator
  • Sensoready(R) pen or prefilled syringe: Discard any unused product
  • Administer each injection at a different anatomic location (eg, upper arms, thighs, or any quadrant of abdomen) than the previous injection; avoid areas where skin is tender, bruised, erythematous, indurated, or affected by psoriasis

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• Tuberculosis infection; before, during, and after treatment.
  • Exacerbation of Crohn disease; patients with active Crohn disease.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to report symptoms of infection.
  • Side effects may include nasopharyngitis, upper respiratory tract infection, or diarrhea.
  • Instruct patient to avoid live vaccinations during therapy.
  • Teach patient proper technique and placement of injections.
